ground_truth: Young Don Price shines his flashlight on Edward, and a recap of earlier football, baseball, and basketball highlights reveals that Edward beats Don every time, leaving Edward dumbstruck. With all the strength he can muster, he turns and walks down the front steps while she stays in the doorway for a few beats, feeling genuinely horrible for what's happened, but eventually, she goes back inside. We lead Edward as he walks away, tears just starting to form, and he exits the frame, leaving only the sorority house in the background. Edward steps back into the frame, looking at the sorority house, as we circle and he shouts. Sandra and her sisters peer out through the curtains while the tweedy economics professor continues his explanation, but Sandra isn't paying a lot of attention. He switches on the overhead projector without looking at it, causing a titter from the students, but he doesn't notice until a classmate nudges Sandra, who looks up and the professor finally notices what's written there. Walking with her books, Sandra shakes her head, disbelieving, and we look up to the blue sky where a giant sky-written heart floats in the wind. At her sisters' prompting, a just-woken Sandra looks out the second-story window to find the lawn filled with Edward standing amid the sea of flowers. Sandra walks out to him, smiling, confused, joyful, and scared, and out of nowhere, a tear drops down Sandra's cheek. From down the street, the adult Don Price arrives, 230 pounds of football-playing, Skynyrd-loving, fraternity-proud muscle, and he's pissed. A gang of his brothers walk behind him, and Don Price decks him, knocking him down. Edward gets right back up but makes no move to defend himself, unfazed; Don slugs him again, shrugs fine, then proceeds to kick Edward's ass nine ways to Sunday, and as the ass-whupping continues, we see Don Price sitting on the can, pinching a loaf while reading the new Playboy, squeezing down hard, trying to shit the unshittable. Suddenly, he grasps his chest and collapses face-first on the tile, and the same image of Don's dead face on the tile is reflected in The Eye as the thrashing continues. Edward somehow fights his way back to his feet, ready to be knocked down again, and Don is about to slug Edward again when he turns as Sandra pulls off her engagement ring. There's an audible AHH! from her sisters and an OHH! from Don's brothers, and Don stands stunned, his mind reeling. Edward, whose eyes are swollen almost shut, keeps waiting for the next punch as she hands him the ring. Another beat passes, then Don storms off, and Sandra leans over Edward's broken body, his head lying on the daffodils. As the music reaches a crescendo, Edward reaches for his glass of water, but Josephine already has it for him.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: Young Don Price, with a determined expression, shines his flashlight directly on Edward. A recap of earlier sports highlights—football, baseball, and basketball—plays out, illustrating that Edward consistently outperforms Don in every instance, leaving Edward utterly dumbstruck by his own success. Summoning all the strength he can muster, Edward turns and descends the front steps, while she remains standing in the doorway for a few lingering moments, feeling genuinely terrible about the events that have transpired. Eventually, she retreats back inside. We follow Edward as he walks away, tears just beginning to form in his eyes, and he exits the frame, leaving only the sorority house visible in the background. Edward re-enters the frame, casting a glance back at the sorority house, and as we circle around him, he shouts. Inside, Sandra and her sisters peer out through the curtains, while the tweedy economics professor continues his lecture, but Sandra is not paying much attention. He switches on the overhead projector without glancing at it, eliciting a titter from the students, but he remains oblivious until a classmate nudges Sandra, prompting her to look up, and the professor finally notices the writing there. Walking with her books in hand, Sandra shakes her head in disbelief, and we gaze up at the expansive blue sky where a giant sky-written heart drifts in the wind. At her sisters' urging, a just-awakened Sandra looks out the second-story window to discover the lawn filled with Edward, standing amidst a sea of flowers. Sandra walks out to him, her emotions a mix of confusion, joy, and fear, and unexpectedly, a tear rolls down her cheek. From down the street, the adult Don Price arrives, a formidable 230 pounds of football-playing, Skynyrd-loving, fraternity-proud muscle, and he is visibly angry. A group of his fraternity brothers follows behind him, and Don Price punches Edward, knocking him to the ground. Edward immediately gets back up but makes no attempt to defend himself, remaining unfazed; Don hits him again, shrugs it off, and proceeds to beat Edward mercilessly. As the beating continues, we see Don Price sitting on the toilet, reading the latest issue of Playboy, straining hard, trying to accomplish the impossible. Suddenly, he clutches his chest and collapses face-first onto the tile floor, and the same image of Don's lifeless face on the tile is reflected in The Eye as the thrashing continues. Edward somehow manages to fight his way back to his feet, ready to be knocked down once more, and Don is about to hit Edward again when he turns to see Sandra removing her engagement ring. There's an audible gasp of "AHH!" from her sisters and an "OHH!" from Don's brothers, leaving Don standing there, stunned, his mind reeling. Edward, whose eyes are swollen almost shut, continues to brace himself for the next punch as she hands him the ring. Another moment passes, then Don storms off, and Sandra leans over Edward's battered body, his head resting on the daffodils. As the music swells to a crescendo, Edward reaches for his glass of water, but Josephine is already there, holding it for him.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: Young Don Price, wearing a resolute and focused look, directs the beam of his flashlight unwaveringly on Edward. The scene shifts to recount earlier sports highlights, showcasing football, baseball, and basketball events. In every one of these, Edward consistently surpasses Don, performing at a level so remarkable that it leaves Edward himself in a state of sheer astonishment at his unexpected triumphs. Gathering every ounce of strength within him, Edward turns away and carefully descends the steps at the front. Meanwhile, she lingers in the doorway, standing there for a few more moments, genuinely feeling a profound sense of regret and sorrow about the events that have unfolded. After those fleeting moments pass, she slowly retreats back indoors. Our focus shifts to Edward as he walks on, tears just beginning to well up in his eyes, eventually disappearing from the frame, leaving only the sorority house as the backdrop. Edward reappears in the frame, glancing back towards the sorority house, and as the camera encircles him, he lets out a shout. Inside, Sandra and her sorority sisters peer out through the curtains, while the tweedy economics professor continues delivering his lecture. However, Sandra’s mind is elsewhere, and she is not paying much attention to the lecture. The professor, obliviously switching on the overhead projector without even glancing at it, inadvertently provokes quiet laughter from the students. It isn’t until a classmate gently nudges Sandra, prompting her to look up, that the professor finally notices the writing projected there. Carrying her books, Sandra walks on, shaking her head in disbelief, and we shift our gaze upward to the vast, expansive blue sky where a giant heart, written in the sky, drifts serenely in the wind. At the urging of her sisters, a freshly awakened Sandra peers out from the second-story window and is taken aback to find the lawn adorned with Edward standing amidst a sea of vibrant flowers. Sandra steps out to meet him, her emotions a whirlwind of confusion, joy, and fear, and quite unexpectedly, a single tear trickles down her cheek. Meanwhile, from down the street, the adult Don Price makes his entrance, weighing in at a formidable 230 pounds of robust, football-playing, Skynyrd-loving, fraternity-proud muscle, and his anger is visibly palpable. Trailing behind him are a group of his fraternity brothers, and in a sudden burst of rage, Don Price punches Edward, knocking him to the ground. Yet, Edward immediately gets back up, not making any attempt to defend himself, and seeming completely unfazed; with each hit from Don, Edward simply shrugs it off, but Don continues to beat Edward mercilessly. As the brutal beating continues relentlessly, we see a parallel scene with Don Price sitting grimly on the toilet, engrossed in reading the latest issue of Playboy, straining intensely, trying to achieve the impossible. Without warning, he clutches his chest and collapses face-first onto the cold tile floor, and the identical haunting image of Don's lifeless face on the tile is mirrored in The Eye as the thrashing persists. Against all odds, Edward somehow manages to struggle back to his feet, preparing himself once more for another fall. Just as Don is about to strike Edward again, his attention is diverted by the sight of Sandra removing her engagement ring. The sound of an audible gasp, "AHH!" emanates from her sisters, while an "OHH!" escapes from Don's fraternity brothers, leaving Don standing there, utterly stunned, his mind spinning. Despite his eyes being almost swollen shut, Edward continues to brace himself for yet another punch as she reaches out to hand him the ring. Another moment hangs in the air, then Don storms off in a huff, and Sandra leans tenderly over Edward's battered and bruised body, his head resting gently among the daffodils. As the music swells and crescendos with intensity, Edward reaches for his glass of water, but Josephine is already by his side, holding it for him with care.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Young Don Price directs the beam of his flashlight onto Edward, illuminating his face as a series of earlier sports highlights flash through his mind, each one showcasing Edward's consistent victories over Don in football, baseball, and basketball, leaving Edward in a state of disbelief. Summoning all his remaining strength, Edward turns away and begins to descend the front steps, each step deliberate and heavy with emotion, while she lingers in the doorway for a few moments, her heart weighed down by genuine remorse for the events that have transpired, before she eventually retreats back inside. We follow Edward as he continues his walk, his pace slow and burdened, tears beginning to well up in his eyes as he moves out of the frame, leaving the sorority house as the sole backdrop. Edward reappears in the frame, his gaze fixed on the sorority house, and as we circle around him, he raises his voice in a shout. Inside, Sandra and her sisters peek through the curtains, their curiosity piqued, while the tweedy economics professor carries on with his lecture, oblivious to Sandra's lack of attention. He absentmindedly switches on the overhead projector, eliciting a ripple of laughter from the students, which he fails to notice until a classmate nudges Sandra, prompting her to look up, and only then does the professor become aware of the writing on the projector. As Sandra walks with her books, she shakes her head in disbelief, and we shift our gaze to the expansive blue sky where a giant heart, crafted from skywriting, drifts gently in the wind. At the urging of her sisters, a groggy Sandra peers out from the second-story window to discover the lawn below, awash with flowers, and Edward standing amidst them. Sandra steps out to meet him, her emotions a complex mix of confusion, joy, and fear, and unexpectedly, a tear slips down her cheek. From down the street, the adult Don Price approaches, his imposing 230-pound frame, honed by football and fueled by a love for Skynyrd and fraternity pride, radiating anger. Accompanied by a group of his fraternity brothers, Don Price lands a punch on Edward, sending him to the ground. Edward rises immediately, making no attempt to defend himself, seemingly unfazed, as Don strikes him again, then nonchalantly continues to pummel Edward with relentless force. As the beating persists, we catch a glimpse of Don Price in a different setting, sitting on the toilet, engrossed in the latest issue of Playboy, straining with all his might to accomplish the impossible. Abruptly, he clutches his chest and collapses forward, his face meeting the cold tile floor, and this image of Don's lifeless face is mirrored in The Eye as the thrashing continues. Despite the odds, Edward manages to struggle back to his feet, bracing himself for another blow, and just as Don is about to strike again, he pauses as Sandra removes her engagement ring. The sound of her sisters' collective gasp and the surprised exclamations from Don's brothers fill the air, leaving Don momentarily paralyzed, his mind struggling to process the scene. Edward, his eyes nearly swollen shut, remains poised for the next punch, but instead, Sandra extends the ring to him. A moment of silence ensues before Don storms off in a fit of frustration, and Sandra bends over Edward's battered body, his head resting gently on the daffodils. As the music swells to a dramatic peak, Edward reaches out for his glass of water, but Josephine is already there, handing it to him with care.

test_cases.description: Young Don Price shines his flashlight on Edward, revealing a series of sports highlights where Edward consistently outperforms Don, leaving Edward dumbstruck. Summoning his strength, Edward walks away from the scene, while she lingers in the doorway, feeling remorseful before retreating inside. Despite being knocked down repeatedly, Edward remains unfazed and doesn't defend himself. As Don continues the assault, a scene of Don's demise is intercut, showing him collapsing in a bathroom. Edward, battered but resilient, stands again as Sandra removes her engagement ring, stunning Don and eliciting reactions from the onlookers. Don storms off, and Sandra tends to Edward's broken body, lying among the daffodils. As the music crescendos, Edward reaches for his glass of water, which Josephine already holds for him.

He switches on the overhead projector without looking at it, causing a titter from the students, but he doesn't notice until a classmate nudges Sandra, who looks up and the professor finally notices what's written there. At her sisters' prompting, a just-woken Sandra looks out the second-story window to find the lawn filled with Edward standing amid the sea of flowers, an extravagant display that stops everyone in their tracks. Sandra walks out to him, smiling, confused, joyful, and scared, and out of nowhere, a tear drops down Sandra's cheek. From down the street, the adult Don Price arrives, 230 pounds of football-playing, Skynyrd-loving, fraternity-proud muscle, and he's pissed, remembering his high school glory days, now overshadowed by Edward's persistent presence. A gang of his brothers, known for their rowdy antics on and off the field, walk behind him, and Don Price decks him, knocking him down. Edward gets right back up but makes no move to defend himself, unfazed; Don slugs him again, shrugs fine, then proceeds to kick Edward's ass nine ways to Sunday, and as the ass-whupping continues, we see Don Price sitting on the can, pinching a loaf while reading the new Playboy, squeezing down hard, trying to shit the unshittable. Suddenly, he grasps his chest, a shock of pain that signifies more than just indigestion, and collapses face-first on the tile, and the same image of Don's dead face on the tile is reflected in The Eye, an ominous symbol suggesting fate's watchful gaze, as the thrashing continues. Edward somehow fights his way back to his feet, ready to be knocked down again, and Don is about to slug Edward again when he turns as Sandra pulls off her engagement ring, a symbol of commitment now broken. There's an audible AHH! from her sisters and an OHH! from Don's brothers, all deeply entrenched in the drama, and Don stands stunned, his mind reeling from the spectacle and its implications. Edward, whose eyes are swollen almost shut, keeps waiting for the next punch as she hands him the ring, an act of defiance and newfound love. Another beat passes, then Don storms off, and Sandra leans over Edward's broken body, his head lying on the daffodils, a flower long associated with rebirth and new beginnings. As the music, a sweeping orchestral piece that underscores the emotional intensity, reaches a crescendo, Edward reaches for his glass of water, but Josephine, ever attentive, already has it for him.

Don slugs him again shrugs fine then proceeds to kick Edward's ass nine ways to Sunday and as the asswhupping continues we see Don Price sitting on the can pinching a loaf while reading the new Playboy squeezing down hard trying to shit the unshittable. Suddenly he grasps his chest and collapses facefirst on the tile and the same image of Don's dead face on the tile is reflected in The Eye as the thrashing continues. Edward somehow fights his way back to his feet ready to be knocked down again and Don is about to slug Edward again when he turns as Sandra pulls off her engagement ring. There is an audible AHH from her sisters and an OHH from Don's brothers and Don stands stunned his mind reeling. Edward whose eyes are swollen almost shut keeps waiting for the next punch as she hands him the ring. Another beat passes then Don storms off and Sandra leans over Edward's broken body his head lying on the daffodils. As the music reaches a crescendo Edward reaches for his glass of water but Josephine already has it for him.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Young Don Price polishes his binoculars on Edward, and a recap of earlier cricket, tennis, and golf highlights shows that Edward underestimates Don every time, leaving Edward astounded. Sandra walks over to him, beaming, bemused, thrilled, and anxious, and out of nowhere, a smile forms on Sandra's lips. From down the street, the adult Don Price arrives, 230 pounds of football-playing, Skynyrd-loving, fraternity-proud muscle, and he's thrilled. A gang of his brothers skip behind him, and Don Price tickles him, knocking him down. Edward springs right back up but makes no move to laugh at himself, amused; Don pats him again, nods affirmatively, then proceeds to compliment Edward's efforts nine ways to Sunday, and as the praise continues, we see Don Price sitting on a bench, enjoying a sandwich while reading the new Playboy, munching down hard, trying to digest the indigestible. Suddenly, he clutches his stomach and collapses face-first on the grass, and the same image of Don's grinning face on the grass is reflected in The Eye as the compliments continue. Edward somehow dances his way back to his feet, ready to be tickled again, and Don is about to poke Edward again when he pauses as Sandra removes her engagement ring. There's an audible AHH! from her sisters and an OHH! from Don's brothers, and Don stands surprised, his mind processing. Edward, whose eyes are shining with joy, keeps waiting for the next laugh as she hands him the ring. Another beat passes, then Don skips off, and Sandra leans over Edward's smiling body, his head resting on the daffodils. As the music reaches a crescendo, Edward reaches for his spoon, but Josephine already has it for him.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption

At her roommates' urging, a barely-awake Patricia peers out the second-floor window to find the grass covered with Harold standing amid the sea of tulips. Patricia walks out to him, grinning, puzzled, delighted, and anxious, and from nowhere, a smile breaks on Patricia's face. From up the avenue, the mature Marvin arrives, 230 pounds of rugby-playing, Zeppelin-loving, club-proud brawn, and he's furious. A cluster of his buddies trail behind him, and Marvin pushes him, sending him sprawling. Harold stands right back up but decides not to shield himself, unbothered; Marvin punches him again, shrugs fine, then goes on to pummel Harold's physique tirelessly, and as the thrashing carries on, we see Marvin perched on the sofa, skimming the new Rolling Stone, concentrating hard, trying to decipher the undecipherable. Harold somehow rises back to his feet, ready to be flattened again, and Marvin is about to strike Harold again when he pivots as Patricia removes her bracelet. There's an audible GASP! from her roommates and an AWW! from Marvin's buddies, and Marvin stands startled, his thoughts spinning. Harold, whose gaze is almost obscured, keeps anticipating the next hit as she offers him the bracelet. test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Young Don Price exposes Edward as the superior athlete through sport highlights. Disheartened, Edward walks away, leaving the sorority house in the background. As Sandra peers through the curtains during class, an overhead projector snafu amuses the students. Later, a sky-written heart captures her attention. Awoken by her sisters, Sandra looks out to find Edward surrounded by flowers, making her smile through tears. Enraged, adult Don Price, with his fraternity brothers, confronts Edward and beats him. Despite the attack, Edward persists in standing up. Don, preparing another strike, halts as Sandra removes her engagement ring. The crowd reacts audibly as Don processes the shock. Defeated, Don leaves while Sandra tends to Edward, lying among the daffodils. At a musical peak, Edward reaches for water, but Josephine offers it to him first.

test_cases.name: Jumble Segments Order
test_cases.description: Edward somehow fights his way back to his feet ready to be knocked down again and Don is about to slug Edward again when he turns as Sandra pulls off her engagement ring  Sandra walks out to him smiling confused joyful and scared and out of nowhere a tear drops down Sandra's cheek  Edward steps back into the frame looking at the sorority house as we circle and he shouts  A gang of his brothers walk behind him and Don Price decks him knocking him down  Skynyrdloving fraternityproud muscle and he's pissed  Suddenly he grasps his chest and collapses facefirst on the tile and the same image of Don's dead face on the tile is reflected in The Eye as the thrashing continues  With all the strength he can muster he turns and walks down the front steps while she stays in the doorway for a few beats feeling genuinely horrible for what's happened but eventually she goes back inside  Edward whose eyes are swollen almost shut keeps waiting for the next punch as she hands him the ring  He switches on the overhead projector without looking at it causing a titter from the students but he doesn't notice until a classmate nudges Sandra who looks up and the professor finally notices what's written there  Another beat passes then Don storms off and Sandra leans over Edward's broken body his head lying on the daffodils  We lead Edward as he walks away tears just starting to form and he exits the frame leaving only the sorority house in the background  Young Don Price shines his flashlight on Edward and a recap of earlier football baseball and basketball highlights reveals that Edward beats Don every time leaving Edward dumbstruck  Edward gets right back up but makes no move to defend himself unfazed  Sandra and her sisters peer out through the curtains while the tweedy economics professor continues his explanation but Sandra isn't paying a lot of attention  From down the street the adult Don Price arrives 230 pounds of footballplaying  nine ways to Sunday and as the asswhupping continues we see Don Price sitting on the can pinching a loaf while reading the new Playboy squeezing down hard trying to shit the unshittable  At her sisters' prompting a justwoken Sandra looks out the secondstory window to find the lawn filled with Edward standing amid the sea of flowers  Don slugs him again shrugs fine then proceeds to kick Edward's ass  As the music reaches a crescendo Edward reaches for his glass of water but Josephine already has it for him Walking with her books Sandra shakes her head disbelieving and we look up to the blue sky where a giant skywritten heart floats in the wind  There's an audible AHH from her sisters and an OHH from Don's brothers and Don stands stunned his mind reeling
